name: Harare
fun_fact: Fun fact: Harare is known as the 'City of Flowering Trees' with over 2.5 million jacaranda trees that bloom bright purple every October, transforming the entire city into a lavender wonderland.

hero_dishes.name: Sadza with Nyama and Muriwo
hero_dishes.description: Thick maize meal porridge (sadza) served with stewed beef (nyama) and braised leafy greens (muriwo) - Zimbabwe's soul food
hero_dishes.origin_story: Sadza is the cornerstone of Zimbabwean cuisine, eaten daily by families across the country. The dish represents agricultural heritage - maize was introduced centuries ago and became the staple grain. Breaking off a piece of sadza with your hands and using it to scoop relish is the traditional way to eat.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gava's Restaurant (Belgravia Sports Club - 'Sadza With Soul'), Mr Sadza Restaurant (traditional Zimbabwean vibes), Garwe Restaurant (Eastlea - authentic unwritten menu described by your host)

hero_dishes.name: Oxtail Stew
hero_dishes.description: Slow-cooked oxtail in rich gravy until the meat falls off the bone, deeply savory and satisfying
hero_dishes.origin_story: Oxtail cooking emerged from traditional nose-to-tail eating practices. In Zimbabwe, this cut is prized for its flavor and gelatinous texture when slow-cooked. It's considered a special occasion dish.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gava's Restaurant (outstanding oxtail with sadza and greens), local family-run restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Whole Fried Fish
hero_dishes.description: Freshwater bream or tilapia from Lake Kariba, fried whole until crispy and served with sadza
hero_dishes.origin_story: Lake Kariba, one of the world's largest man-made lakes, provides fresh fish to Harare's markets. Frying whole fish over high heat creates crispy skin while keeping the meat moist - a technique perfected in Zimbabwean kitchens.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gava's Restaurant (whole fried fish is outstanding), local markets and fish specialist restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Tripe (Matumbu)
hero_dishes.description: Slow-cooked beef tripe in tomato-based sauce, tender and flavorful
hero_dishes.origin_story: Tripe cooking demonstrates traditional resourcefulness - using every part of the animal. When properly prepared, it's a delicacy. Zimbabwean cooks have perfected the long, slow cooking required to make tripe tender.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gava's Restaurant (great authentic value), Mr Sadza Restaurant, Organikks Ndizvo (organic ingredients)

signature_drinks.name: Maheu
signature_drinks.description: Traditional fermented drink made from maize meal, slightly sour and refreshing
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served cold as a nutritious beverage, especially popular with children. It's slightly thick, naturally fermented, and has probiotic benefits. Often homemade but also sold commercially.

signature_drinks.name: Chibuku Shake-Shake
signature_drinks.description: Traditional opaque beer made from maize and sorghum, served in distinctive cartons
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Shaken before drinking (hence the name) and shared communally. It's low in alcohol, nutritious, and deeply cultural. Drinking from the carton and passing it around is traditional.

food_culture_notes: Eating sadza with your hands is the traditional method - using the right hand to break off a piece and scoop up relish
Gava's Restaurant serves al fresco dining under tents on Belgravia Sports Club's bowling green, decorated with local artists' paintings
The quintessential Zimbabwean meal is beef stew with sadza and greens - simple but deeply satisfying when done right
Traditional Zimbabwean restaurants often don't have written menus - the host describes what's available that day based on fresh ingredients
